comments.author: dholbert@mozilla.com
comments.creator: dholbert@mozilla.com
comments.text:
I was directed to https://services.mozilla.com/status/ by clicking on a "server status" button in a Sync error notification.

https://services.mozilla.com/status/ has this weird barely-visible transparent twitter image which just links to twitter:
  https://twitter-widgets.s3.amazonaws.com/i/widget-logo.png

That image probably wants to be replaced with a visible one? (or made to be colorful/visible somehow via CSS hacks?)
comments.raw_text:
I was directed to https://services.mozilla.com/status/ by clicking on a "server status" button in a Sync error notification.

https://services.mozilla.com/status/ has this weird barely-visible transparent twitter image which just links to twitter:
  https://twitter-widgets.s3.amazonaws.com/i/widget-logo.png

That image probably wants to be replaced with a visible one? (or made to be colorful/visible somehow via CSS hacks?)

comments.creator: dholbert@mozilla.com

comments.raw_text: Do you have noscript and/or some sort of  script restriction?  That's a twitter widget for me.
comments.text: Do you have noscript and/or some sort of  script restriction?  That's a twitter widget for me.

dholbert@mozilla.com
comments.author: dholbert@mozilla.com
comments.raw_text:
Hmm - I did test in a 'fresh-ish' profile, but it's possible that profile had noscript installed from a noscript-related bug I was testing a while back.

However, I just now tested in a truly-fresh profile, and now I see the twitter widget, but the barely-visible image is still there below it. (see screenshot)
comments.text:
Created attachment 542386
screenshot #2

Hmm - I did test in a 'fresh-ish' profile, but it's possible that profile had noscript installed from a noscript-related bug I was testing a while back.

However, I just now tested in a truly-fresh profile, and now I see the twitter widget, but the barely-visible image is still there below it. (see screenshot)

comments.author: dholbert@mozilla.com
comments.creator: dholbert@mozilla.com
comments.text: (Maybe that's just how twitter brands its widgets? seems strange to me.)
comments.raw_text: (Maybe that's just how twitter brands its widgets? seems strange to me.)
